intro: Gussonea bieleri, commonly known as the Bieler's gussonea, is a rare and specialized plant native to the high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, often in mountainous or alpine areas. Its flowers are small and white, arranged in umbels, and it produces a distinctive, aromatic scent. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Gussonea bieleri is considered a vulnerable species.
